column1: ap 08:40|"twenty minutes to nine"|"The passage was a long one
column2: and seemed to pervade the whole square basement of the Manor House. We traversed but one side of the square
column3: however
column4: and at the end of it she stopped
column5: and put her candle down and opened a door. Here
column6: the daylight reappeared
column7: and I found myself in a small paved courtyard
column8: the opposite side of which was formed by a detached dwelling-house
column9: that looked as if it had once belonged to the manager or head clerk of the extinct brewery. There was a clock in the outer wall of this house. Like the clock in Miss Havisham’s room
column10: and like Miss Havisham’s watch
column11: it had stopped at twenty minutes to nine."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 12:00|noon|"On the broad landing between Miss Havisham’s own room and that other room in which the long table was laid out
column2: I saw a garden-chair
column3: —a light chair on wheels
column4: that you pushed from behind. It had been placed there since my last visit
column5: and I entered
column6: that same day
column7: on a regular occupation of pushing Miss Havisham in this chair (when she was tired of walking with her hand upon my shoulder) round her own room
column8: and across the landing
column9: and round the other room. Over and over and over again
column10: we would make these journeys
column11: and sometimes they would last as long as three hours at a stretch. I insensibly fall into a general mention of these journeys as numerous
column12: because it was at once settled that I should return every alternate day at noon for these purposes
column13: and because I am now going to sum up a period of at least eight or ten months."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 22:00|"ten o’clock at night"|"When I got home at night
column2: and delivered this message for Joe
column3: my sister “went on the Rampage
column4: ” in a more alarming degree than at any previous period. She asked me and Joe whether we supposed she was door-mats under our feet
column5: and how we dared to use her so
column6: and what company we graciously thought she was fit for? When she had exhausted a torrent of such inquiries
column7: she threw a candlestick at Joe
column8: burst into a loud sobbing
column9: got out the dustpan
column10: —which was always a very bad sign
column11: —put on her coarse apron
column12: and began cleaning up to a terrible extent. Not satisfied with a dry cleaning
column13: she took to a pail and scrubbing-brush
column14: and cleaned us out of house and home
column15: so that we stood shivering in the back-yard. It was ten o’clock at night before we ventured to creep in again
column16: and then she asked Joe why he hadn’t married a Negress Slave at once? Joe offered no answer
column18: but stood feeling his whisker and looking dejectedly at me
column19: as if he thought it really might have been a better speculation."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: < 12:00|"almost noon"|"When we came to Pumblechook’s
column2: my sister bounced in and left us. As it was almost noon
column3: Joe and I held straight on to Miss Havisham’s house. Estella opened the gate as usual
column4: and
column5: the moment she appeared
column6: Joe took his hat off and stood weighing it by the brim in both his hands; as if he had some urgent reason in his mind for being particular to half a quarter of an ounce."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 21:30|"half-past nine o’ clock that night"|"As I never assisted at any other representation of George Barnwell
column2: I don’t know how long it may usually take; but I know very well that it took until half-past nine o’ clock that night
column3: and that when Mr. Wopsle got into Newgate
column4: I thought he never would go to the scaffold
column5: he became so much slower than at any former period of his disgraceful career. I thought it a little too much that he should complain of being cut short in his flower after all
column6: as if he had not been running to seed
column7: leaf after leaf
column8: ever since his course began. This
column9: however
column10: was a mere question of length and wearisomeness. What stung me
column11: was the identification of the whole affair with my unoffending self. When Barnwell began to go wrong
column12: I declare that I felt positively apologetic
column13: Pumblechook’s indignant stare so taxed me with it. Wopsle
column15: took pains to present me in the worst light. At once ferocious and maudlin
column16: I was made to murder my uncle with no extenuating circumstances whatever; Millwood put me down in argument
column17: on every occasion; it became sheer monomania in my master’s daughter to care a button for me; and all I can say for my gasping and procrastinating conduct on the fatal morning
column19: that it was worthy of the general feebleness of my character. Even after I was happily hanged and Wopsle had closed the book
column25: take warning!” as if it were a well-known fact that I contemplated murdering a near relation
column26: provided I could only induce one to have the weakness to become my benefactor."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 11:00|"eleven o’clock"|"Thus
column2: we came to the village. The way by which we approached it took us past the Three Jolly Bargemen
column3: which we were surprised to find—it being eleven o’clock —in a state of commotion
column4: with the door wide open
column5: and unwonted lights that had been hastily caught up and put down scattered about. Mr. Wopsle dropped in to ask what was the matter (surmising that a convict had been taken)
column6: but came running out in a great hurry."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:15|"quarter after eight o’clock"|"Joe had been at the Three Jolly Bargemen
column2: smoking his pipe
column3: from a quarter after eight o’clock to a quarter before ten. While he was there
column4: my sister had been seen standing at the kitchen door
column5: and had exchanged Good Night with a farm-laborer going home. The man could not be more particular as to the time at which he saw her (he got into dense confusion when he tried to be)
column6: than that it must have been before nine. When Joe went home at five minutes before ten
column7: he found her struck down on the floor
column8: and promptly called in assistance. The fire had not then burnt unusually low
column9: nor was the snuff of the candle very long; the candle
column10: however
column11: had been blown out."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:45|"quarter before ten"|"Joe had been at the Three Jolly Bargemen
column2: smoking his pipe
column3: from a quarter after eight o’clock to a quarter before ten. While he was there
column4: my sister had been seen standing at the kitchen door
column5: and had exchanged Good Night with a farm-laborer going home. The man could not be more particular as to the time at which he saw her (he got into dense confusion when he tried to be)
column6: than that it must have been before nine. When Joe went home at five minutes before ten
column7: he found her struck down on the floor
column8: and promptly called in assistance. The fire had not then burnt unusually low
column9: nor was the snuff of the candle very long; the candle
column10: however
column11: had been blown out."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column10: however
column11: had been blown out."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column2: smoking his pipe
column3: from a quarter after eight o’clock to a quarter before ten. While he was there
column4: my sister had been seen standing at the kitchen door
column5: and had exchanged Good Night with a farm-laborer going home. The man could not be more particular as to the time at which he saw her (he got into dense confusion when he tried to be)
column6: than that it must have been before nine. When Joe went home at five minutes before ten

column10: however
column11: had been blown out."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 07:00|"seven o’clock"|"After this memorable event
column2: I went to the hatter’s
column3: and the bootmaker’s
column4: and the hosier’s
column5: and felt rather like Mother Hubbard’s dog whose outfit required the services of so many trades. I also went to the coach-office and took my place for seven o’clock on Saturday morning. It was not necessary to explain everywhere that I had come into a handsome property; but whenever I said anything to that effect
column6: it followed that the officiating tradesman ceased to have his attention diverted through the window by the High Street
column7: and concentrated his mind upon me. When I had ordered everything I wanted
column8: I directed my steps towards Pumblechook’s
column9: and
column10: as I approached that gentleman’s place of business
column11: I saw him standing at his door."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 05:00|"five in the morning"|"I was to leave our village at five in the morning
column2: carrying my little hand-portmanteau
column3: and I had told Joe that I wished to walk away all alone. I am afraid—sore afraid—that this purpose originated in my sense of the contrast there would be between me and Joe
column4: if we went to the coach together. I had pretended with myself that there was nothing of this taint in the arrangement; but when I went up to my little room on this last night
column5: I felt compelled to admit that it might be so
column6: and had an impulse upon me to go down again and entreat Joe to walk with me in the morning. I did not."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 07:53|"seven to eight"|"It was Christmas Eve
column2: and I had to stir the pudding for next day
column3: with a copper-stick
column4: from seven to eight by the Dutch clock. I tried it with the load upon my leg (and that made me think afresh of the man with the load on his leg)
column5: and found the tendency of exercise to bring the bread and butter out at my ankle
column6: quite unmanageable. Happily I slipped away
column7: and deposited that part of my conscience in my garret bedroom."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: > 12:00|"a little past midday"|"The journey from our town to the metropolis was a journey of about five hours. It was a little past midday when the four-horse stage-coach by which I was a passenger
column2: got into the ravel of traffic frayed out about the Cross Keys
column3: Wood Street
column4: Cheapside
column5: London."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 08:00|"eight in the morning"|"While I looked about me here
column2: an exceedingly dirty and partially drunk minister of justice asked me if I would like to step in and hear a trial or so: informing me that he could give me a front place for half a crown
column3: whence I should command a full view of the Lord Chief Justice in his wig and robes
column4: —mentioning that awful personage like waxwork
column5: and presently offering him at the reduced price of eighteen-pence. As I declined the proposal on the plea of an appointment
column6: he was so good as to take me into a yard and show me where the gallows was kept
column7: and also where people were publicly whipped
column8: and then he showed me the Debtors’ Door
column9: out of which culprits came to be hanged; heightening the interest of that dreadful portal by giving me to understand that “four on ’em” would come out at that door the day after to-morrow at eight in the morning
column10: to be killed in a row. This was horrible
column11: and gave me a sickening idea of London; the more so as the Lord Chief Justice’s proprietor wore (from his hat down to his boots and up again to his pocket-handkerchief inclusive) mildewed clothes which had evidently not belonged to him originally
column12: and which I took it into my head he had bought cheap of the executioner. Under these circumstances I thought myself well rid of him for a shilling."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 12:00|midday|"“Dear me!” he exclaimed. “I am extremely sorry; but I knew there was a coach from your part of the country at midday
column2: and I thought you would come by that one. The fact is
column3: I have been out on your account
column4: —not that that is any excuse
column5: —for I thought
column6: coming from the country
column7: you might like a little fruit after dinner
column8: and I went to Covent Garden Market to get it good.”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:40|"twenty minutes to nine"|"“Which she received
column2: ” I struck in
column3: “when she was dressing for her marriage? At twenty minutes to nine?”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:45|"quarter before nine"|"On the Monday morning at a quarter before nine
column2: Herbert went to the counting-house to report himself
column3: —to look about him
column4: too
column5: I suppose
column6: —and I bore him company. He was to come away in an hour or two to attend me to Hammersmith
column7: and I was to wait about for him. It appeared to me that the eggs from which young Insurers were hatched were incubated in dust and heat
column8: like the eggs of ostriches
column9: judging from the places to which those incipient giants repaired on a Monday morning. Nor did the counting-house where Herbert assisted
column10: show in my eyes as at all a good Observatory; being a back second floor up a yard
column11: of a grimy presence in all particulars
column12: and with a look into another back second floor
column13: rather than a look out."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 12:00|noon|"I waited about until it was noon
column2: and I went upon ‘Change
column3: and I saw fluey men sitting there under the bills about shipping
column4: whom I took to be great merchants
column5: though I couldn’t understand why they should all be out of spirits. When Herbert came
column6: we went and had lunch at a celebrated house which I then quite venerated
column7: but now believe to have been the most abject superstition in Europe
column8: and where I could not help noticing
column9: even then
column10: that there was much more gravy on the tablecloths and knives and waiters’ clothes
column11: than in the steaks. This collation disposed of at a moderate price (considering the grease
column12: which was not charged for)
column13: we went back to Barnard’s Inn and got my little portmanteau
column14: and then took coach for Hammersmith. We arrived there at two or three o’clock in the afternoon
column15: and had very little way to walk to Mr. Pocket’s house. Lifting the latch of a gate
column16: we passed direct into a little garden overlooking the river
column17: where Mr. Pocket’s children were playing about. And unless I deceive myself on a point where my interests or prepossessions are certainly not concerned
column18: I saw that Mr. and Mrs. Pocket’s children were not growing up or being brought up
column19: but were tumbling up."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column8: and where I could not help noticing

column18: I saw that Mr. and Mrs. Pocket’s children were not growing up or being brought up

column1: ap 06:00|"six o’clock"|"I had not seen Mr. Wemmick for some weeks
column2: when I thought I would write him a note and propose to go home with him on a certain evening. He replied that it would give him much pleasure
column3: and that he would expect me at the office at six o’clock. Thither I went
column4: and there I found him
column5: putting the key of his safe down his back as the clock struck."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o’clock"|"“At nine o’clock every night
column2: Greenwich time
column3: ” said Wemmick
column4: “the gun fires. There he is
column5: you see! And when you hear him go
column6: I think you’ll say he’s a Stinger.”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap < 09:00|"almost nine o’clock"|"Of course I felt my good faith involved in the observance of his request. The punch being very nice
column2: we sat there drinking it and talking
column3: until it was almost nine o’clock. “Getting near gun-fire
column4: ” said Wemmick then
column5: as he laid down his pipe; “it’s the Aged’s treat.”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:30|"half-past eight"|"Wemmick was up early in the morning
column2: and I am afraid I heard him cleaning my boots. After that
column3: he fell to gardening
column4: and I saw him from my gothic window pretending to employ the Aged
column5: and nodding at him in a most devoted manner. Our breakfast was as good as the supper
column6: and at half-past eight precisely we started for Little Britain. By degrees
column7: Wemmick got dryer and harder as we went along
column8: and his mouth tightened into a post-office again. At last
column9: when we got to his place of business and he pulled out his key from his coat-collar
column10: he looked as unconscious of his Walworth property as if the Castle and the drawbridge and the arbor and the lake and the fountain and the Aged
column11: had all been blown into space together by the last discharge of the Stinger."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 06:00|"six o’clock"|"It fell out as Wemmick had told me it would
column2: that I had an early opportunity of comparing my guardian’s establishment with that of his cashier and clerk. My guardian was in his room
column3: washing his hands with his scented soap
column4: when I went into the office from Walworth; and he called me to him
column5: and gave me the invitation for myself and friends which Wemmick had prepared me to receive. “No ceremony
column6: ” he stipulated
column7: “and no dinner dress
column8: and say to-morrow.” I asked him where we should come to (for I had no idea where he lived)
column9: and I believe it was in his general objection to make anything like an admission
column10: that he replied
column11: “Come here
column12: and I’ll take you home with me.” I embrace this opportunity of remarking that he washed his clients off
column13: as if he were a surgeon or a dentist. He had a closet in his room
column15: which smelt of the scented soap like a perfumer’s shop. It had an unusually large jack-towel on a roller inside the door
column16: and he would wash his hands
column17: and wipe them and dry them all over this towel
column18: whenever he came in from a police court or dismissed a client from his room. When I and my friends repaired to him at six o’clock next day
column19: he seemed to have been engaged on a case of a darker complexion than usual
column20: for we found him with his head butted into this closet
column22: but laving his face and gargling his throat. And even when he had done all that
column23: and had gone all round the jack-towel
column24: he took out his penknife and scraped the case out of his nails before he put his coat on."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:30|"half-past nine"|"“At half-past nine
column2: gentlemen
column3: ” said he
column4: “we must break up. Pray make the best use of your time. I am glad to see you all. Mr. Drummle
column5: I drink to you.”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:30|"half past nine"|"“Gentlemen
column2: ” said Mr. Jaggers
column3: deliberately putting down the glass
column4: and hauling out his gold repeater by its massive chain
column5: “I am exceedingly sorry to announce that it’s half past nine.”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o’clock"|"“I write this by request of Mr. Gargery
column2: for to let you know that he is going to London in company with Mr. Wopsle and would be glad if agreeable to be allowed to see you. He would call at Barnard’s Hotel Tuesday morning at nine o’clock
column3: when if not agreeable please leave word. Your poor sister is much the same as when you left. We talk of you in the kitchen every night
column4: and wonder what you are saying and doing. If now considered in the light of a liberty
column5: excuse it for the love of poor old days. No more
column6: dear Mr. Pip
column7: from your ever obliged
column8: and affectionate servant
column9: |Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:00|eight|"This avenging phantom was ordered to be on duty at eight on Tuesday morning in the hall
column2: (it was two feet square
column3: as charged for floorcloth
column4: ) and Herbert suggested certain things for breakfast that he thought Joe would like. While I felt sincerely obliged to him for being so interested and considerate
column5: I had an odd half-provoked sense of suspicion upon me
column6: that if Joe had been coming to see him
column7: he wouldn’t have been quite so brisk about it."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 02:00|"two o’clock"|"It was the afternoon coach by which I had taken my place
column2: and
column3: as winter had now come round
column4: I should not arrive at my destination until two or three hours after dark. Our time of starting from the Cross Keys was two o’clock. I arrived on the ground with a quarter of an hour to spare
column5: attended by the Avenger
column6: —if I may connect that expression with one who never attended on me if he could possibly help it."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o’clock"|"We played until nine o’clock
column2: and then it was arranged that when Estella came to London I should be forewarned of her coming and should meet her at the coach; and then I took leave of her
column3: and touched her and left her."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 12:00|midday|"As we were going back together to London by the midday coach
column2: and as I breakfasted under such terrors of Pumblechook that I could scarcely hold my cup
column3: this gave me an opportunity of saying that I wanted a walk
column4: and that I would go on along the London road while Mr. Jaggers was occupied
column5: if he would let the coachman know that I would get into my place when overtaken. I was thus enabled to fly from the Blue Boar immediately after breakfast. By then making a loop of about a couple of miles into the open country at the back of Pumblechook’s premises
column6: I got round into the High Street again
column7: a little beyond that pitfall
column8: and felt myself in comparative security."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 02:00|"two o’clock in the morning"|"Without distinctly knowing whether I should have been more sorry for Mr. Wopsle if he had been in despair
column2: I was so sorry for him as it was
column3: that I took the opportunity of his turning round to have his braces put on
column4: —which jostled us out at the doorway
column5: —to ask Herbert what he thought of having him home to supper? Herbert said he thought it would be kind to do so; therefore I invited him
column6: and he went to Barnard’s with us
column7: wrapped up to the eyes
column8: and we did our best for him
column9: and he sat until two o’clock in the morning
column10: reviewing his success and developing his plans. I forget in detail what they were
column11: but I have a general recollection that he was to begin with reviving the Drama
column12: and to end with crushing it; inasmuch as his decease would leave it utterly bereft and without a chance or hope."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 12:00|midday|"“I am to come to London the day after to-morrow by the midday coach. I believe it was settled you should meet me? At all events Miss Havisham has that impression
column2: and I write in obedience to it. She sends you her regard."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ~ 12:00|"about mid-day"|"In my confidence in my own resources
column2: I would willingly have taken Herbert’s expenses on myself; but Herbert was proud
column3: and I could make no such proposal to him. So he got into difficulties in every direction
column4: and continued to look about him. When we gradually fell into keeping late hours and late company
column5: I noticed that he looked about him with a desponding eye at breakfast-time; that he began to look about him more hopefully about mid-day; that he drooped when he came into dinner; that he seemed to descry Capital in the distance
column6: rather clearly
column7: after dinner; that he all but realized Capital towards midnight; and that at about two o’clock in the morning
column8: he became so deeply despondent again as to talk of buying a rifle and going to America
column9: with a general purpose of compelling buffaloes to make his fortune."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: < 00:00|"towards midnight"|"In my confidence in my own resources
column2: I would willingly have taken Herbert’s expenses on myself; but Herbert was proud
column3: and I could make no such proposal to him. So he got into difficulties in every direction
column4: and continued to look about him. When we gradually fell into keeping late hours and late company
column5: I noticed that he looked about him with a desponding eye at breakfast-time; that he began to look about him more hopefully about mid-day; that he drooped when he came into dinner; that he seemed to descry Capital in the distance
column6: rather clearly
column7: after dinner; that he all but realized Capital towards midnight; and that at about two o’clock in the morning
column8: he became so deeply despondent again as to talk of buying a rifle and going to America
column9: with a general purpose of compelling buffaloes to make his fortune."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ~ 02:00|"about two o’clock in the morning"|"In my confidence in my own resources
column2: I would willingly have taken Herbert’s expenses on myself; but Herbert was proud
column3: and I could make no such proposal to him. So he got into difficulties in every direction
column4: and continued to look about him. When we gradually fell into keeping late hours and late company
column5: I noticed that he looked about him with a desponding eye at breakfast-time; that he began to look about him more hopefully about mid-day; that he drooped when he came into dinner; that he seemed to descry Capital in the distance
column6: rather clearly
column7: after dinner; that he all but realized Capital towards midnight; and that at about two o’clock in the morning
column8: he became so deeply despondent again as to talk of buying a rifle and going to America
column9: with a general purpose of compelling buffaloes to make his fortune."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 18:20|"twenty minutes past six in the evening"|"The letter was signed Trabb & Co.
column2: and its contents were simply
column3: that I was an honored sir
column4: and that they begged to inform me that Mrs. J. Gargery had departed this life on Monday last at twenty minutes past six in the evening
column5: and that my attendance was requested at the interment on Monday next at three o’clock in the afternoon."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 15:00|"three o’clock in the afternoon"|"The letter was signed Trabb & Co.
column2: and its contents were simply
column3: that I was an honored sir
column4: and that they begged to inform me that Mrs. J. Gargery had departed this life on Monday last at twenty minutes past six in the evening
column5: and that my attendance was requested at the interment on Monday next at three o’clock in the afternoon."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 17:00|"five in the afternoon"|"I had taken care to have it well understood in Little Britain when my birthday was. On the day before it
column2: I received an official note from Wemmick
column3: informing me that Mr. Jaggers would be glad if I would call upon him at five in the afternoon of the auspicious day. This convinced us that something great was to happen
column4: and threw me into an unusual flutter when I repaired to my guardian’s office
column5: a model of punctuality."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap < 02:00|"towards two o’clock"|"I lay in that separate building across the courtyard. It was the first time I had ever lain down to rest in Satis House
column2: and sleep refused to come near me. A thousand Miss Havishams haunted me. She was on this side of my pillow
column3: on that
column4: at the head of the bed
column5: at the foot
column6: behind the half-opened door of the dressing-room
column7: in the dressing-room
column8: in the room overhead
column9: in the room beneath
column10: — everywhere. At last
column11: when the night was slow to creep on towards two o’clock
column12: I felt that I absolutely could no longer bear the place as a place to lie down in
column13: and that I must get up. I therefore got up and put on my clothes
column14: and went out across the yard into the long stone passage
column15: designing to gain the outer courtyard and walk there for the relief of my mind. But I was no sooner in the passage than I extinguished my candle; for I saw Miss Havisham going along it in a ghostly manner
column16: making a low cry. I followed her at a distance
column17: and saw her go up the staircase. She carried a bare candle in her hand
column18: which she had probably taken from one of the sconces in her own room
column19: and was a most unearthly object by its light. Standing at the bottom of the staircase
column20: I felt the mildewed air of the feast-chamber
column21: without seeing her open the door
column22: and I heard her walking there
column23: and so across into her own room
column24: and so across again into that
column25: never ceasing the low cry. After a time
column26: I tried in the dark both to get out
column28: but I could do neither until some streaks of day strayed in and showed me where to lay my hands. During the whole interval
column29: whenever I went to the bottom of the staircase
column32: and heard her ceaseless low cry."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 11:00|"eleven o’clock"|"I read with my watch upon the table
column2: purposing to close my book at eleven o’clock. As I shut it
column3: Saint Paul’s
column4: and all the many church-clocks in the City—some leading
column5: some accompanying
column6: some following—struck that hour. The sound was curiously flawed by the wind; and I was listening
column7: and thinking how the wind assailed and tore it
column8: when I heard a footstep on the stair."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 05:00|five|"He had rolled a handkerchief round his head
column2: and his face was set and lowering in his sleep. But he was asleep
column3: and quietly too
column4: though he had a pistol lying on the pillow. Assured of this
column5: I softly removed the key to the outside of his door
column6: and turned it on him before I again sat down by the fire. Gradually I slipped from the chair and lay on the floor. When I awoke without having parted in my sleep with the perception of my wretchedness
column7: the clocks of the Eastward churches were striking five
column8: the candles were wasted out
column9: the fire was dead
column10: and the wind and rain intensified the thick black darkness."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 01:30|"half-past one"|"Mr. Wopsle
column2: the clerk at church
column3: was to dine with us; and Mr. Hubble the wheelwright and Mrs. Hubble; and Uncle Pumblechook (Joe’s uncle
column4: but Mrs. Joe appropriated him)
column5: who was a well-to-do cornchandler in the nearest town
column6: and drove his own chaise-cart. The dinner hour was half-past one. When Joe and I got home
column7: we found the table laid
column8: and Mrs. Joe dressed
column9: and the dinner dressing
column10: and the front door unlocked (it never was at any other time) for the company to enter by
column11: and everything most splendid. And still
column12: not a word of the robbery."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap ~ 11:00|"about eleven o’clock"|"“The night being so bad
column2: sir
column3: ” said the watchman
column4: as he gave me back my glass
column5: “uncommon few have come in at my gate. Besides them three gentlemen that I have named
column6: I don’t call to mind another since about eleven o’clock
column7: when a stranger asked for you.”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"I lighted my fire
column2: which burnt with a raw pale flare at that time of the morning
column3: and fell into a doze before it. I seemed to have been dozing a whole night when the clocks struck six. As there was full an hour and a half between me and daylight
column4: I dozed again; now
column5: waking up uneasily
column6: with prolix conversations about nothing
column7: in my ears; now
column8: making thunder of the wind in the chimney; at length
column9: falling off into a profound sleep from which the daylight woke me with a start."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 15:00|"three in the afternoon"|"It would seem a simple matter to decide on these precautions; but in my dazed
column2: not to say distracted
column3: state
column4: it took so long
column5: that I did not get out to further them until two or three in the afternoon. He was to remain shut up in the chambers while I was gone
column6: and was on no account to open the door."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"Herbert said
column2: “Certainly
column3: ” but looked as if there were no specific consolation in this
column4: and remained perplexed and dismayed. We were anxious for the time when he would go to his lodging and leave us together
column5: but he was evidently jealous of leaving us together
column6: and sat late. It was midnight before I took him round to Essex Street
column7: and saw him safely in at his own dark door. When it closed upon him
column8: I experienced the first moment of relief I had known since the night of his arrival."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 05:00|"five in the morning"|"“I might a took warning by Arthur
column2: but I didn’t; and I won’t pretend I was partick’ler—for where ‘ud be the good on it
column3: dear boy and comrade? So I begun wi’ Compeyson
column4: and a poor tool I was in his hands. Arthur lived at the top of Compeyson’s house (over nigh Brentford it was)
column5: and Compeyson kept a careful account agen him for board and lodging
column6: in case he should ever get better to work it out. But Arthur soon settled the account. The second or third time as ever I see him
column7: he come a tearing down into Compeyson’s parlor late at night
column8: in only a flannel gown
column9: with his hair all in a sweat
column10: and he says to Compeyson’s wife
column11: ‘Sally
column12: she really is upstairs alonger me
column13: now
column14: and I can’t get rid of her. She’s all in white
column18: and she’s got a shroud hanging over her arm
column19: and she says she’ll put it on me at five in the morning.’"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap < 05:00|"a few minutes of five"|"“He rested pretty quiet till it might want a few minutes of five
column2: and then he starts up with a scream
column3: and screams out
column4: ‘Here she is! She’s got the shroud again. She’s unfolding it. She’s coming out of the corner. She’s coming to the bed. Hold me
column5: both on you—one of each side—don’t let her touch me with it. Hah! she missed me that time. Don’t let her throw it over my shoulders. Don’t let her lift me up to get it round me. She’s lifting me up. Keep me down!’ Then he lifted himself up hard
column6: and was dead."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: > 00:00|"past midnight"|"It was past midnight when I crossed London Bridge. Pursuing the narrow intricacies of the streets which at that time tended westward near the Middlesex shore of the river
column2: my readiest access to the Temple was close by the river-side
column3: through Whitefriars. I was not expected till to-morrow; but I had my keys
column4: and
column5: if Herbert were gone to bed
column6: could get to bed myself without disturbing him."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 07:00|seven|"I had left directions that I was to be called at seven; for it was plain that I must see Wemmick before seeing any one else
column2: and equally plain that this was a case in which his Walworth sentiments only could be taken. It was a relief to get out of the room where the night had been so miserable
column3: and I needed no second knocking at the door to startle me from my uneasy bed."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:00|"eight o’clock"|"The Castle battlements arose upon my view at eight o’clock. The little servant happening to be entering the fortress with two hot rolls
column2: I passed through the postern and crossed the drawbridge in her company
column3: and so came without announcement into the presence of Wemmick as he was making tea for himself and the Aged. An open door afforded a perspective view of the Aged in bed."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o’clock"|"“Well
column2: sir! Mr. Herbert threw himself into the business with a will
column3: and by nine o’clock last night he housed Tom
column4: Jack
column5: or Richard
column6: — whichever it may be
column7: —you and I don’t want to know
column8: —quite successfully. At the old lodgings it was understood that he was summoned to Dover
column9: and
column10: in fact
column11: he was taken down the Dover road and cornered out of it. Now
column12: another great advantage of all this is
column13: that it was done without you
column15: if any one was concerning himself about your movements
column16: you must be known to be ever so many miles off and quite otherwise engaged. This diverts suspicion and confuses it; and for the same reason I recommended that
column17: even if you came back last night
column18: you should not go home. It brings in more confusion
column19: and you want confusion.”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:00|"Eight o’clock"|"Eight o’clock had struck before I got into the air
column2: that was scented
column3: not disagreeably
column4: by the chips and shavings of the long-shore boat-builders
column5: and mast
column6: oar
column7: and block makers. All that water-side region of the upper and lower Pool below Bridge was unknown ground to me; and when I struck down by the river
column8: I found that the spot I wanted was not where I had supposed it to be
column9: and was anything but easy to find. It was called Mill Pond Bank
column10: Chinks’s Basin; and I had no other guide to Chinks’s Basin than the Old Green Copper Rope-walk."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 00:00|twelve|"When Mr. Wopsle had imparted to me all that he could recall or I extract
column2: and when I had treated him to a little appropriate refreshment
column3: after the fatigues of the evening
column4: we parted. It was between twelve and one o’clock when I reached the Temple
column5: and the gates were shut. No one was near me when I went in and went home."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 01:00|"one o’clock"|"When Mr. Wopsle had imparted to me all that he could recall or I extract
column2: and when I had treated him to a little appropriate refreshment
column3: after the fatigues of the evening
column4: we parted. It was between twelve and one o’clock when I reached the Temple
column5: and the gates were shut. No one was near me when I went in and went home."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: < 00:00|"Towards midnight"|"There was a stage
column2: that evening
column3: when she spoke collectedly of what had happened
column4: though with a certain terrible vivacity. Towards midnight she began to wander in her speech; and after that it gradually set in that she said innumerable times in a low solemn voice
column5: “What have I done!” And then
column6: “When she first came
column7: I meant to save her from misery like mine.” And then
column8: “Take the pencil and write under my name
column9: ‘I forgive her!’” She never changed the order of these three sentences
column10: but she sometimes left out a word in one or other of them; never putting in another word
column11: but always leaving a blank and going on to the next word."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap ~ 06:00|"about six o’clock"|"As I could do no service there
column2: and as I had
column3: nearer home
column4: that pressing reason for anxiety and fear which even her wanderings could not drive out of my mind
column5: I decided
column6: in the course of the night that I would return by the early morning coach
column7: walking on a mile or so
column8: and being taken up clear of the town. At about six o’clock of the morning
column9: therefore
column10: I leaned over her and touched her lips with mine
column11: just as they said
column12: not stopping for being touched
column13: “Take the pencil and write under my name

column1: ap ~ 02:30|"just gone half past two"|"“Would you give me the time?” said the sergeant
column2: addressing himself to Mr. Pumblechook
column3: as to a man whose appreciative powers justified the inference that he was equal to the time.

column1: “It’s just gone half past two.”
“That’s not so bad
column2: ” said the sergeant
column3: reflecting; “even if I was forced to halt here nigh two hours
column4: that’ll do. How far might you call yourselves from the marshes
column5: hereabouts? Not above a mile
column6: I reckon?”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 01:00|"one o’clock"|"Herbert assented to all this
column2: and we went out immediately after breakfast to pursue our investigations. We found that a steamer for Hamburg was likely to suit our purpose best
column3: and we directed our thoughts chiefly to that vessel. But we noted down what other foreign steamers would leave London with the same tide
column4: and we satisfied ourselves that we knew the build and color of each. We then separated for a few hours: I
column5: to get at once such passports as were necessary; Herbert
column6: to see Startop at his lodgings. We both did what we had to do without any hindrance
column7: and when we met again at one o’clock reported it done. I
column8: for my part
column9: was prepared with passports; Herbert had seen Startop
column10: and he was more than ready to join."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap > 09:00|"past nine"|"It rose under my hand
column2: and the door yielded. Looking in
column3: I saw a lighted candle on a table
column4: a bench
column5: and a mattress on a truckle bedstead. As there was a loft above
column6: I called
column7: “Is there any one here?” but no voice answered. Then I looked at my watch
column8: and
column9: finding that it was past nine
column10: called again
column11: “Is there any one here?” There being still no answer
column12: I went out at the door
column13: irresolute what to do."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ~ 00:00|"About midnight"|"They kept me very quiet all day
column2: and kept my arm constantly dressed
column3: and gave me cooling drinks. Whenever I fell asleep
column4: I awoke with the notion I had had in the sluice-house
column5: that a long time had elapsed and the opportunity to save him was gone. About midnight I got out of bed and went to Herbert
column6: with the conviction that I had been asleep for four-and-twenty hours
column7: and that Wednesday was past. It was the last self-exhausting effort of my fretfulness
column8: for after that I slept soundly."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o’clock"|"“When it turns at nine o’clock
column2: ” said Herbert
column3: cheerfully
column4: “look out for us
column5: and stand ready
column6: you over there at Mill Pond Bank!”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:30|"half-past eight"|"We loitered down to the Temple stairs
column2: and stood loitering there
column3: as if we were not quite decided to go upon the water at all. Of course
column4: I had taken care that the boat should be ready and everything in order. After a little show of indecision
column5: which there were none to see but the two or three amphibious creatures belonging to our Temple stairs
column6: we went on board and cast off; Herbert in the bow
column7: I steering. It was then about high-water
column8: — half-past eight."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 09:00|nine|"Our plan was this. The tide
column2: beginning to run down at nine
column3: and being with us until three
column4: we intended still to creep on after it had turned
column5: and row against it until dark. We should then be well in those long reaches below Gravesend
column6: between Kent and Essex
column7: where the river is broad and solitary
column8: where the water-side inhabitants are very few
column9: and where lone public-houses are scattered here and there
column10: of which we could choose one for a resting-place. There
column11: we meant to lie by all night. The steamer for Hamburg and the steamer for Rotterdam would start from London at about nine on Thursday morning. We should know at what time to expect them
column12: according to where we were
column13: and would hail the first; so that
column14: if by any accident we were not taken abroad
column15: we should have another chance. We knew the distinguishing marks of each vessel."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ~ 13:00|"about one in the afternoon"|"This dialogue made us all uneasy
column2: and me very uneasy. The dismal wind was muttering round the house
column3: the tide was flapping at the shore
column4: and I had a feeling that we were caged and threatened. A four-oared galley hovering about in so unusual a way as to attract this notice was an ugly circumstance that I could not get rid of. When I had induced Provis to go up to bed
column5: I went outside with my two companions (Startop by this time knew the state of the case)
column6: and held another council. Whether we should remain at the house until near the steamer’s time
column7: which would be about one in the afternoon
column8: or whether we should put off early in the morning
column9: was the question we discussed. On the whole we deemed it the better course to lie where we were
column10: until within an hour or so of the steamer’s time
column11: and then to get out in her track
column12: and drift easily with the tide. Having settled to do this
column13: we returned into the house and went to bed."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ~ 12:00|"about noon"|"We were up early. As we walked to and fro
column2: all four together
column3: before breakfast
column4: I deemed it right to recount what I had seen. Again our charge was the least anxious of the party. It was very likely that the men belonged to the Custom House
column5: he said quietly
column6: and that they had no thought of us. I tried to persuade myself that it was so
column7: —as
column8: indeed
column9: it might easily be. However
column10: I proposed that he and I should walk away together to a distant point we could see
column11: and that the boat should take us aboard there
column12: or as near there as might prove feasible
column13: at about noon. This being considered a good precaution
column14: soon after breakfast he and I set forth
column15: without saying anything at the tavern."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 00:50|"ten minutes of one o’clock"|"When he looked out from his shelter in the distance
column2: and saw that I waved my hat to him to come up
column3: he rejoined me
column4: and there we waited; sometimes lying on the bank
column5: wrapped in our coats
column6: and sometimes moving about to warm ourselves
column7: until we saw our boat coming round. We got aboard easily
column8: and rowed out into the track of the steamer. By that time it wanted but ten minutes of one o’clock
column9: and we began to look out for her smoke."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 01:30|"half-past one"|"But
column2: it was half-past one before we saw her smoke
column3: and soon afterwards we saw behind it the smoke of another steamer. As they were coming on at full speed
column4: we got the two bags ready
column5: and took that opportunity of saying good by to Herbert and Startop. We had all shaken hands cordially
column6: and neither Herbert’s eyes nor mine were quite dry
column7: when I saw a four-oared galley shoot out from under the bank but a little way ahead of us
column8: and row out into the same track."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:30|"half past eight"|"He had done so much for me at various times
column2: that this was very little to do for him. I said I could manage it
column3: —would manage it
column4: — and he was so very much pleased by my acquiescence
column5: that I was pleased too. At his particular request
column6: I appointed to call for him at the Castle at half past eight on Monday morning
column7: and so we parted for the time."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:00|Eight|"“However
column2: ” said Joe
column3: rising to replenish the fire; “here’s the Dutch-clock a working himself up to being equal to strike Eight of ’em
column4: and she’s not come home yet! I hope Uncle Pumblechook’s mare mayn’t have set a forefoot on a piece o’ ice
column5: and gone down.”"|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:00|"eight o’clock"|"Mr. Pumblechook and I breakfasted at eight o’clock in the parlor behind the shop
column2: while the shopman took his mug of tea and hunch of bread and butter on a sack of peas in the front premises. I considered Mr. Pumblechook wretched company. Besides being possessed by my sister’s idea that a mortifying and penitential character ought to be imparted to my diet
column3: —besides giving me as much crumb as possible in combination with as little butter
column4: and putting such a quantity of warm water into my milk that it would have been more candid to have left the milk out altogether
column5: —his conversation consisted of nothing but arithmetic. On my politely bidding him Good morning
column6: he said
column7: pompously
column8: “Seven times nine
column9: boy?” And how should I be able to answer
column10: dodged in that way
column11: in a strange place
column12: on an empty stomach! I was hungry
column13: but before I had swallowed a morsel
column14: he began a running sum that lasted all through the breakfast. “Seven?” “And four?” “And eight?” “And six?” “And two?” “And ten?” And so on. And after each figure was disposed of
column15: it was as much as I could do to get a bite or a sup
column16: before the next came; while he sat at his ease guessing nothing
column17: and eating bacon and hot roll
column18: in (if I may be allowed the expression) a gorging and gormandizing manner."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 10:00|"ten o’clock"|"For such reasons
column2: I was very glad when ten o’clock came and we started for Miss Havisham’s; though I was not at all at my ease regarding the manner in which I should acquit myself under that lady’s roof. Within a quarter of an hour we came to Miss Havisham’s house
column3: which was of old brick
column4: and dismal
column5: and had a great many iron bars to it. Some of the windows had been walled up; of those that remained
column6: all the lower were rustily barred. There was a courtyard in front
column7: and that was barred; so we had to wait
column8: after ringing the bell
column9: until some one should come to open it. While we waited at the gate
column10: I peeped in (even then Mr. Pumblechook said
column11: “And fourteen?” but I pretended not to hear him)
column12: and saw that at the side of the house there was a large brewery. No brewing was going on in it
column13: and none seemed to have gone on for a long long time."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: ap 08:40|"twenty minutes to nine"|"It was when I stood before her
column2: avoiding her eyes
column3: that I took note of the surrounding objects in detail
column4: and saw that her watch had stopped at twenty minutes to nine
column5: and that a clock in the room had stopped at twenty minutes to nine."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"

column1: 02:30|vigils|"My sister’s bringing up had made me sensitive. In the little world in which children have their existence whosoever brings them up
column2: there is nothing so finely perceived and so finely felt as injustice. It may be only small injustice that the child can be exposed to; but the child is small
column3: and its world is small
column4: and its rocking-horse stands as many hands high
column5: according to scale
column6: as a big-boned Irish hunter. Within myself
column7: I had sustained
column8: from my babyhood
column9: a perpetual conflict with injustice. I had known
column10: from the time when I could speak
column11: that my sister
column12: in her capricious and violent coercion
column13: was unjust to me. I had cherished a profound conviction that her bringing me up by hand gave her no right to bring me up by jerks. Through all my punishments
column18: I had nursed this assurance; and to my communing so much with it
column19: in a solitary and unprotected way
column20: I in great part refer the fact that I was morally timid and very sensitive."|"Great Expectations"|"Charles Dickens"
